The purist in me says you put the DAO interfaces in your application project
(or their very own project/module/jar). The DAO impls go in their own
project (project/module/jar). Then, you write unit tests for the DAO impls
in the dao impl project. That way, you only "need" the database when running
unit tests for the DAOs, you use a mocking tool to mockup the DAO interfaces
in your application project. At that point, you can write your service layer
unit tests. You then mock-up the service layer interfaces and start writing
struts action unit tests.

If you write service layer unit tests that depend on a real database, then
you've not written unit tests, you've written integration tests. The same
goes for struts action tests that depend on a real service layer.

The pragmatist in me says write your DOA impl unit tests to run against the
database. Then write your service unit tests with a dependency on you
database (just recognize that these are integration tests). Skip the struts
action unit tests. There should be NO business logic in a struts action and
really little other logic other than mapping and service calls.

When you write your DAO impl unit tests, you need to make sure that you
circumvent the DAO layer for test setup and verification. If you use the DAO
implementations to setup and verify, then you are testing stuff, but you
cannot define what you are testing.

--dlm
